title: About
text: My name is Caleb Clark and I am a third year student at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln. This website was created to highlight some of the stories I have created and help people learn more about college sports. I also play baseball here at UNL and I hope to showcase some data from our season. I am from Canada and I enjoy all things sports. Thank you for clicking on my website and I hope you enjoy these stories!

title: Huskers rebounding is really good… and really bad. How?
text:
During the 2023-2024 men’s college basketball season, the Nebraska Cornhuskers ranked within the top 70 in total rebounds. They worked hard to dominate on the defensive end and it paid off ranking within the top 20. Their issue? Getting second chances on the offensive side. Nebraska ranked 241st in Division one basketball in offensive rebounding and struggled in their biggest moments which led to an early exit in the tournament.
The question is: How can you dominate but also struggle doing the exact same thing but opposite ends of the court?


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(waffle)
library(ggplot2)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
#| message: FALSE
basketball <- read_csv("logs24.csv")
big_ten_data <- basketball %>%
  filter(Conference == "Big Ten") %>%
  group_by(Team) %>%
  summarise(
    Total_Offensive_Rebounds = sum(TeamOffRebounds, na.rm = TRUE),
    Total_Rebounds = sum(TeamTotalRebounds, na.rm = TRUE), 
  ) |>
  arrange(desc(Total_Rebounds), desc(Total_Offensive_Rebounds))  
waffle_data <- big_ten_data %>%
  select(Team, Total_Rebounds, Total_Offensive_Rebounds) %>%
  gather(key = "Rebound_Type", value = "Rebounds", Total_Rebounds, Total_Offensive_Rebounds) %>%
  arrange(desc(Rebounds))
nu2 <- c("Total Rebounds"=1176, "Offensive Rebounds"=277)
wi2 <- c("Total Rebounds"=1106, "Offensive Rebounds"=309)

iron(
 waffle(nu2/2, 
        rows = 11, 
        title="Nebraska's Total Rebounds vs Offensive Rebounds", 
        xlab="1 square = 2 rebounds", 
        colors = c("black", "red")
        ),
 waffle(wi2/2, 
        rows = 11, 
         title="Wisconsin's Total Rebounds vs Offensive Rebounds", 
        xlab = "1 square = 2 rebounds",
        colors = c("black", "red"),
      
        )
        
)











Code
nu<-c("Total Rebounds"= 1176, "Offensive Rebounds"= 277, 273)
pu<-c("Total Rebounds"= 1335, "Offensive Rebounds"=391)
iron(
 waffle(nu/2, 
        rows = 13, 
        title="Nebraska's Total Rebounds vs Offensive Rebounds", 
        xlab="1 square = 2 rebounds", 
        colors = c("black", "red", "white")
        ),
 waffle(pu/2, 
        rows = 13, 
         title="Purdue's Total Rebounds vs Offensive Rebounds", 
        xlab = "1 square = 2 rebounds",
        colors = c("black", "red"),
       )
)
